string_table.name: npnxnanbnsnfns00001010001
string_table.string: Closed captions. Press the spacebar to toggle captions on and off.
Skip Navigation. Hit enter to return to the slide.

terms.term: Wearing, rubbing, or grinding away by friction.
1. A position defined in reference to the origin of a coordinate system. 2. A position defined in reference to the home position of a robotic device.
1. The rate of change of an object's velocity with respect to time. 2. Change in either the direction or magnitude of an object's velocity.
An output device which converts electricity to motion.
The portion of the gear tooth that lies outside the pitch circle.
A circle bounding the tips of a gear's teeth.
The temporary molecular attraction between two surfaces in contact with each other.
A set of instructions for accomplishing a task.
A standard, non-rechargeable battery which uses an alkaline electrolyte.
Numerals and letters of the alphabet.
Electricity in which the direction of flow of electrons repeatedly reverses.
(adjective) Having a value from a continuous range of possible values.
An input port to which an analog peripheral device may be connected.
A sensor that reads a value from a range of possible values.
Change in magnitude of an object's angular velocity or spin rate.
The rate at which an object revolves, rotates, or spins. Measured in revolutions per minute (RPM).
The positive electrode of a battery.
A conductor that can transmit and/or receive electromagnetic waves.
The process of joining two heavy, solid pieces of metal with the heat from a high-voltage spark.

A style of controlling a robot?s drive train using one joystick. The controller reads the forward/backward and left/right movement of the joystick to determine the relative speeds of the two sides of the drive train.
A value given to a function to control the performance of the designated task. Also called a parameter.
An assembly of poles, wire windings, and the rotor of an electric motor.
(adjective) Having multiple segments held together by joints.
Storing a value in a variable.
The = operator, used to assign a value to a variable. (Not to be confused with the comparison operator ==).
(adjective) Functioning independently, without human involvement.
Total distance traveled divided by elapsed time.
Displacement divided by elapsed time.
The line about which an objects revolves, rotates or spins. Also called the fulcrum.
The rod on which a wheel or gear rotates. Unlike a shaft, an axle does not transmit torque.
The unwanted activation of a loaded motor after the electrical power has been shut off, usually as a result of external forces applied to a driven component or wheel.
Looseness or slackness in the meshing of gears in a gear train.
A system of representing numbers using only the two digits 1 and 0. Also known as binary.
The basic robot platform for all REC projects.
A device that converts stored chemical energy into electrical energy.
The line of melted material which joins two welded pieces.
A component used to reduce friction between moving parts of a machine.
Cone-shaped gears with teeth cut at an angle with respect to the axis of rotation.
Button Head Cap Screw.
A single binary digit.
In EasyC, a graphical representation of a function or operation.

A logical calculus named for mathematician George Boole, where alphabetic symbols are used to represent logical variable, 1 and 0 are states, and, AND, OR, and NOT are the basic logical operations. NAND and NOR can be represented by combinations of AND, OR and NOT.
The center hole of a gear where the axle or shaft is inserted. The bore often has a keyway cut into it.
The process of creating a pool of ideas for analysis and testing.
The property of a computer program in which program flow has more than one possible path.
An electric motor with electromagnetic coils on the outside stator and an assembly of permanent magnets on the rotor.
A region of computer memory where data is stored temporarily before being transferred to where it is used.
A code or algorithm error. Often hard to find.
A digital sensor that reports zero to the VEX controller when it is in physical contact with an object, and one at all other times.
A unit of computer memory consisting of 8 bits.
A computer programming language.
A plastic fastener used to bundle and secure cables.
(verb) To cause program flow to switch to a function.
Function that is executed by another piece of code. Opposite of caller.
Code that executes a function. Opposite of a callee.

1. In three-dimensional space, a system of coordinates in which the location of a point is defined by reference to distance from planes defined by axes which are placed at right angles to each other. 2. In two-dimensional space, a system of coordinates in which the location of a point is defined by reference to distance from the axes.
A robot which has translational degrees of freedom, but no rotational degrees of freedom.
A wheel in contact with the ground, spinning freely without direct mechanical connection to a motor.
The negative electrode of a battery.
The distance between the centers of two gears that engage one another.
The point about which an object would be balanced. Abbreviated CG, and also known as Center of Mass or Center of Weight.
The point about which an object would be balanced. Also known as Center of Gravity.
The smallest variable type, consisting of 8 bits and having 256 possible values.
The basic structural frame of a machine.
Potential energy stored in the chemical bonds of a compound.
Computer Integrated Manufacturing: an automated assembly line that uses a network of computers to control robots, production machines and quality control devices.
The space between two adjacent objects.
(adjective) Rotating in the same direction as the hands of a clock. Abbreviated CW. Also called negative rotation.
(adjective) Using feedback from sensors as a basis for making program decisions.
A device placed in contact with a rotating part that allows it to slip when the torque exceeds the friction.
Computer Numerical Control: A category of automated machine tools, such as mills, routers and lathes, which operate using Numerical Control (NC) instructions received from a computer program.
Instructions for a computer.
An experimentally determed ratio between the applied normal force and the resulting friction force between two materials in contact with each other.
A metal ring affixed to an axle or shaft which prevents attached components from sliding along the axle or shaft.
A call to a function in a computer programming language.
A non-functional note added to computer code for the benefit of the programmer.
Mechanical device that allows electric current to reverse direction within an electric motor.
An operator used to compare two values.
The process of converting a C-language program into machine code.
An element of a larger system or collection.
An assembly of two gears of different sizes, fixed to a single axle. Also called a stacked gear.
An assembly of gears and axles, in which one or more axles has two gears of differing sizes.
A manufacturing process which is controlled by a computer. Abbreviated CIM.
A socket or plug used to link components together electrically.
A hard-keyed value in the program code which cannot be changed while the program is running.
An unbroken electrical path in an electrical circuit or connector.
A component which contains a computer and connectors for various input and output devices.
A widely used standard or practice, based on general consensus.
A metal, plastic, or ceramic cylinder for wire windings to coil about.
(adjective) Rotating opposite to the direction of the hands of a clock. Abbreviated CCW. Also called positive rotation.
(adjective) In reference to screws, recessed to be flush with the flat surface of a member.
A mechanism in which one link rotates and the opposite link rocks back and forth.
A mechanism in which one link rotates and the opposite link slides back and forth.
A robot with a work envelope in the shape of a cylinder.
An emergency stop switch which shuts down a machine if the operator lets go of the switch.
Navigation without feedback from sensors.
The range of input values which do not produce any output.
Definition of variables together with their variable types and any initial values.
(verb) To decrease the value of a variable.
The portion of a gear tooth that lies inside the pitch circle.
The circle that passes through the bottom of each tooth on a gear.
Change in shape due to the application of force.
The ability of an object or joint to rotate or translate with respect to an axis.
On a gear, the number of teeth per inch, measured along the pitch circle.
(adjective) 1. Represented by discrete numeric values. 2. Represented by binary values.
1. Discrete numeric values transmitted to a computer. 2. Input in the form of binary values (on/off).
A connector for a digital sensor.
1. Discrete numeric values transmitted from a computer. 2. Output in the form of binary values (on/off).
A connector for a digital output device.
A sensor that provides feedback in only 2 possible states, on or off.
Electricity which flows in one direction, from the negative terminal to the positive terminal.
The shortest path between two positions, with reference to both direction and magnitude. (Not to be confused with distance).
1. The shortest possible path between two positions, with reference only to magnitude. 2. The total length of a path from start point to end point.
In EasyC, a real number taking up four bytes. It has six significant figures and can range from -1 x 10^38 to 1 x 10^38. Also called a float.
(verb) To transfer from the desktop computer to the robot. Also used as a noun.
A system of components which transmit mechanical energy from the motor to the wheels.
A gear which receives mechanical energy from another gear.
A gear which transmits mechanical energy to another gear. Also called a driving gear.
An electrical battery whose electrolyte is in the form of a paste rather than a liquid.
The use of sound to determine position based on the return time of the echoes.
The ratio of useful energy output to total energy input.
The flow of electrons through a wire or other conductor.

1. In electronics, a conductor which makes contact with a non-metallic part of an electric circuit. 2. In arc welding, a metal rod which delivers the spark to the pieces being joined, and which also melts to fuse with those pieces.
An electrically conductive ionic solution, in which electrodes of dissimilar metals are placed to create a battery.
A coil of wire which produces a magnetic field when supplied with electricity.
A wave of energy with both electric and magnetic variations. Depending on the frequency, the wave could be radio waves, infrared light, visible light, ultraviolet, X-rays, gamma rays, etc.
A button used to immediately shut down a machine.
(adjective) Based on observation.
A device which converts motion into a series of electrical pulses.
A device attached to the end of a movable arm, which can effect change in the environment of a machine. Also called a manipulator.
A quantity representing the ability to perform work.
The process used in engineering design, consisting of Problem Identification, Brainstorming, Analysis, Prototyping, Testing and Optimization, and Presentation.
A notebook which contains all notes relevant to the development of a patentable product.
A triangle where all sides are of equal length and each angle is 60 degrees.
The state at which the motion of an object does not change.
(verb) 1. To start a computer program. 2. To continue following the instructions of a computer program. Synonymous with 'to run'.
In mathematics: A symbol or combination of symbols that represents a quantity or a relationship between quantities.
Not true. In programming, a value of 0. By convention, always written in capital letters.
A mechanical device that joins two or more objects together.
The US Government agency which regulates the use of radio frequencies. Abbreviated FCC.
Received data used to regulate the output of a system.
A connector socket that a male connector fits into.
In EasyC, a real number taking up four bytes of memory. It has six significant figures and can range from -1 x 10^38 to 1 x 10^38. Also called a double.
A decimal value between whole numbers.
A diagram showing a sequence of operations.
Anything that causes the motion of a physical system to change.
A mechanism consisting of four links arranged in the shape of a parallelogram.
The maximum angular velocity that a motor can achieve when unattached to a drive train and not loaded with weight. Also called no-load RPM.
The number of times per second something happens, measured in Hertz (Hz).
The number of waves, vibrations, etc. per second.
1. The number of times per second something happens, measured in Hertz (Hz). 2. The number of waves, vibrations, etc. per second.
The force of physical contact that opposes the motion of an object.
1. The pivot point of a lever. 2. The axis of rotation of a moment arm.
A prepackaged sequence of program instructions which can be called from any place within the program.
A bridge-like crane which moves along a set of parallel tracks instead of rotating about a central pivot.
An enclosed module containing a system of compound gears used to produce a larger effective gear ratio than would be practical with a single set of gears.
The slipping of gears past one another because the teeth do not mesh properly.
A single module containing a motor and a sealed gear train to provide a predetermined output.
The ratio of the number of teeth on the input gear to the number of teeth on the output gear.
A set of gears with a gear ratio less than 1, such that the output speed is less than the input speed, but the output torque is greater than the input torque.
An assembly of gears between the motor and the moving part controlled by the motor.
A variable which exists in memory as long as the program is running and is available for use by the entire program.
A pincer-like end effector designed to grab objects.
(noun) 1. An electrical connection to the Earth. 2. An electrical connection to the chassis of an electrical device. 3. (verb) To make a connection between an object and the electrical ground.
A metal plate designed to join parts at a specific angle.
To use a switch or other impossible-to-ignore hardware device to cause a processor to stop all current operations and restart the program.
A cylindrical gear with teeth in the shape of spirals.
A unit of power.
(adjective) Operated or moved by liquid such as water or oil.
An underwater microphone.
The slip of a wheel on a road surface because of a thin intermediate layer of water.

A hypoid is a type of spiral bevel gear whose axis does not intersect with the meshing gear. The basic shape of a hypoid gear is a revolved hyperboloid, whereas the basic shape of a normal spiral bevel gear is a simple cone.
A gear placed between the driver gear and the driven gear, with the same number of teeth as either one so that it extends the reach of the driver gear but does not affect the gear ratio.
A measure of the opposition to the flow of alternating current through a circuit. Impedance is measured in ohms.
Increasing the value of a variable.
The resistance of an object to changes in position or velocity.
The range in the electromagnetic spectrum with a longer wavelength and lower frequency than visible light, and a shorter wavelength and higher frequency than radio waves. Can be felt as heat.
Code that performs all of its operations in one contiguous series of operations with minimal or no use of external functions. Generally quite long and can be hard to read/maintain.
Information going into a computer.
The speed of an object at a given instant.
The velocity of an object at a given instant.
A single step in a computer program.
A variable type which holds 16 bits and has 65,536 possible values.
A natural number (counting number), its negative, or zero.
The ability to gather and apply knowledge.
A ring-shaped gear with teeth on the interior surface.
An external event that interrupts the normal program.
A single cycle through a repeating sequence of steps.
A unit of energy.
A control device consisting of a stick that can be moved forward/backward and left/right.
A programming statement or command that interrupts the normal flow of a program. Examples in C include continue, break, return and goto.
A small rectangular prism of steel that is used to splice a gear and axle into a single assembly.
A rectangular channel cut into the bore hole of a gear or wheel to lock it to an axle.
1. The frictional force between two objects which are in relative motion and in contact with each other. 2. The frictional force between an object and the fluid through which it moves.
An acronym for Keep It Simple, Stupid, the principle that simpler solutions are often better.
A device which emits high-intensity light of a single frequency or wavelength. The acronym LASER stands for Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation.
In the absence of an outside force, an object at rest will stay at rest, and an object in motion will continue moving at the same direction and speed.

If the thumb and first two fingers of the left hand are extended at right angles from one another, with the thumb pointing up and the index finger pointing away from the body, the middle finger is pointed in the positive direction on the X axis, the index finger is pointed in the positive direction on the Y axis, and the thumb is pointed in the positive direction on the Z axis.
A rod or beam which extends from an axis of rotation to a point where force or a load is applied. Also called a moment arm.
A lever where the fulcrum lies between the force exerted and the load.
A lever where the load lies between the force exerted and the fulcrum.
A lever where the force exerted lies between the load and the fulcrum.
An electronic component that emits light as electric current is passed through it. Abbreviated LED.
A switch which controls the limits of travel of a moving part.
(adjective) 1. In a straight line. 2. Made of or pertaining to lines.
Acceleration along a straight line.
Motion along a straight line. Also known as translation or translational motion.
Velocity as measured along a straight line.
A physical connection used to transfer power and motion.
The application of weight to a motor.
A variable which is only temporary, belongs to the associated function, and is created from scratch each time the function is called.
The process by which a robot corrects any accumulated errors between its calculated position and its actual position.
Naturally occurring rock with a magnetic field.
A type of variable that (in the EasyC language) occupies 4 bytes of space.
A sequence of instructions in programming where, immediately after the last instruction, control passes back to the first instruction.
Small letters such as a, b, c, d, etc.
The variable that is on the left side of the equal sign in an assignment operation. For example, in the equation y=x+10, y is the LValue.
The sequence of instructions which a computer is able to use directly.
The region of magnetic influence about a magnet.
A connector with a protruding metal part which fits into a socket.
A device attached to the end of a movable arm, which can effect change in the environment of a machine. Also called an end effector.
A measure of the amount of matter an object possesses. In simplest terms, the amount of stuff that something is made of.
The energy that performs work on an object, causing it to change its motion.
An assembly of parts which perform work.
The portion of a computer which stores data in digital form, including program instructions and variables.
A single chip which contains the central processing unit of a computer.
1/1000 of a second.
A self-contained part that can be easily interchanged.
The remainder when dividing integers. In C, this is done with the % symbol. Abbreviated Mod.
The product of a translational force and the distance between the axis of rotation and the point at which the force is applied.
A rod or beam which extends from a fulcrum to a point where force or a load is applied. Also called a lever arm.
A device which produces mechanical energy.
Carbon rods, held against the commutator to transfer electricity to the windings on the armature of a motor.
The VEX module containing a continuous motor, a speed controller, and a gear box.
(adjective) Capable of performing a variety of tasks.
6076 feet, one minute of arc as measured at the Earth's equator.
Clockwise rotation.
Placement of one loop inside another.
The sum of all forces acting on an object.
The sum of all torques acting on an object.
A unit of force measurement named after Sir Isaac Newton.
A unit of torque or moment. Abbreviated N/m.
An object at rest will remain at rest or an object in motion will remain in motion, unless acted upon by an outside force.
The acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the applied force and inversely proportional to the mass of the object.
For every force (the action), there exists an equal, yet opposite force (the reaction).
Rechargeable batteries in which the electrodes are made of nickel and cadmium.
The maximum angular velocity that a motor can achieve when unattached to a drive train and not loaded with weight. Also called free spin.
Any number which is not a natural number (counting number), its negative, or zero.
The force perpendicular (extending straight out) to a surface.
(adjective) Not using sensor feedback about the environment.
A symbol denoting a computer operation or relationship.
Periodic, repeating motion from one extreme to the other, such as in waves, the swinging of a pendulum or the bouncing of a spring.
Signals from the controller to another device, such as a motor.
A response which is greater than expected from a stimulus.
The apparent shift of a foreground object against a background when the observation point is moved.
If two or more circuit components are connected like the rungs of a ladder it is said they are connected in parallel.

Electrical circuit components can be connected together in one of two ways: series or parallel. These two names describe the method of attaching the components, that is one after the other or next to each other. A parallel circuit is a different path for current through each of its components. A parallel circuit provides the same voltage across all its components.
A four-sided shape in which each side is parallel to the side opposite.
A value given to a function to control the performance of the designated task. Also called an argument.
The act of sending information (usually in a variable) from one piece of code to another, often from code to a function that is being called.
A magnetic object which does not require electricity to produce magnetism.
(adjective) Able to produce electricity when subjected to physical stress or deformity.
A small hole drilled into material before a screw is inserted. The diameter of the pilot hole is usually the root diameter of the screw.
The area of a mechanism, where two hard surfaces come together, creating the potential to close on or pinch an object that enters that area of the mechanism.
The area of a mechanism, where two hard surfaces come together, creating the potential to close on or pinch an object that enters that area of the mechanism.
1. In navigation, a sound emitted by a SONAR device. 2. In telecommunications, a command that sends an echo request to a host with the expectation of a reply.
The smaller of two gears in a gear combination.

1. On a threaded fastener such as a screw or bolt, the distance between the tip of one thread to the tip of the next. 2. On a gear, the distance between the tip of one tooth to the tip of the next. 3. On a chain, the distance between any three consecutive rivets divided by two. 4. Motion tilting forward or backward about a horizontal, transverse axis.
A circle through the points where meshing gear teeth interact.
The diameter of the pitch circle of a gear.
On a gear, the distance between the pitch circle and the center.
A joint that allows rotational movement.
A gear system consisting of one or more outer gears, or planet gears, rotating about a central gear, or sun gear.

planetary gearing is a gear system that consists of one or more outer gears, or planet gears, revolving about a central, or sun gear. Typically, the planet gears are mounted on a movable arm or carrier which itself may rotate relative to the sun gear. Epicyclic
(adjective) Using air to transmit work energy.

1. In three-dimensional space, a system of coordinates in which the location of a point is defined by reference to angle of rotation, angle of elevation and distance from the origin. 2. In two-dimensional space, a system of coordinates in which the location of a point is defined by reference to angle of rotation and distance from the origin.
A robotic arm whose position is defined by the polar coordinate system.
One of two ends of a magnet, designated North and South.
1. Computer hardware: An outlet for connection of a cable. 2. Telecommunications/Internet: A numeric designation indicating which program has originated a request.
In linear motion analysis, a record of time and displacement.
Counter-clockwise rotation.
A variable electrical resistor with a range of possible resistor values. As the potentiometer turns, the resistance increases or decreases.
A unit of force measurement.
A unit of mass defined such that 1 pound mass weighs exactly 1 pound force in Earth gravity at sea level.
A unit of torque or moment. Also called the foot-pound.

To reset a controller by turning off the power, waiting for the internal power supply to use up any residual voltage, and then turning the power back on. Often used to clear a failed condition or restart a program.
The order in which operations are done.
At the point where the face of a gear tooth intersects with the pitch circle, the angle between the gear face and a ray from the center of the gear.
A series of steps.
A system that uses devices such as Programmable Logic Controller, various sensors, and computed algorithms to monitor and maintain a particular manufacturing process.
1. (noun) A series of instructions for controlling a computer, written in code that the computer can understand. 2. (verb) To write a program for a computer.
A hardware interface between a personal computer and the Vex controller.
The property of two quantities which have a constant ratio.
1. In engineering, the first physical model of a design. 2. In computer programming, a declaration of a function, defining the name, parameters and type of return value.
False or fake.
A written representation of what a program does, using plain English instead of computer programming language.

1. In an electrical signal which switches rapidly on and off, modulation of the width of the ON pulses. 2. A method of converting a steady voltage to a variable average voltage by rapidly switching on and off, regulating the ratio of ON time to OFF time. Abbreviated PWM.
A long rectangular prism with gear teeth cut into one of the faces.
A gear train consisting of a spur gear and a rack gear.
A unit for measuring the angular velocity of rotating objects.
The use of radio signals to remotely control another device. Abbreviated RC.
Controlled, gradual acceleration or deceleration.
An instrument for finding the distance of an object.
A powerful permanent magnet made of a combination of neodymium, iron, and boron.
1. Radio control. 2. Remote control.
An electronic device that reads radio waves with an antenna and decodes the radio signals from the transmitter.
An electronic device which converts AC current to DC.
A position relative to another position in a coordinate system.
Control of a machine or apparatus from a distance. Abbreviated RC.
(adjective) Capable of adaptation to new tasks without physical modification.
A word previously defined by a computer programming language and reserved for specific uses.
An electronic component which limits electron flow or current.

Takes place when a function has finished its operation and gives control back to the calling code. When the return operation takes place a value may optionally be passed back from the function to the caller.
1. Rotational movement of an object about a point which is not the center of gravity of the object, and which is outside its physical substance. 2. Rotation.
If the right hand is clasped about an axis, the thumb points in the positive direction on the axis, and the fingers point in the positive direction of rotation.
The outer gear in a planetary gearset.
1. A reprogrammable, multifunctional manipulator. 2. A machine which is controlled partly or completely by computer. 3. A machine in the shape of a human being or other animal.
The combination of rotational and translational motion that occurs when a round object moves in contact with another object without sliding.
The friction that occurs when an object rolls.
The inside measurement of the threaded portion of a screw.
Circular motion around an axis. Example: A wheel rotates about its axle.
The movement of an object in a circular path, as contrasted with a linear path. Synonymous with angular motion, spinning, turning.
The portion of a motor that rotates.
Revolutions per minute; a unit for measuring angular velocity.
(verb) 1. To start a computer program. 2. To continue following the instructions of a computer program. Synonymous with to execute.
The process of reading values from a sensor at regular intervals.
The number of times per second that values are read from a sensor.
Computer code in which the names of the constants and variables reveal precisely what they mean and are being used for.
A device that provides information or feedback to a computer program.
An ordered series of events.
If two or more circuit components are connected end to end like a daisy chain, it is said they are connected in series.

Electrical circuit components can be connected together in one of two ways: series or parallel. These two names describe the method of attaching the components, that is one after the other or next to each other. A series circuit is a single path for current through all of its components.
A module containing a servo motor.
A small, compact, gear head motor with a restricted range of rotational motion.
A machine screw with no head, capable of being screwed all the way into a threaded hole. Usually used to fix something to a shaft.
A rod or beam used to transmit torque.
The smooth portion of a screw or bolt between the head and the threads.
A wheel with a grooved rim for transmitting force to a cable or belt.
A type of variable that (in the EasyC language) occupies 3 bytes of space.
Systeme Internationale - the international system of units.
A type of variable that (in the EasyC language) occupies two bytes of space, and supports positive and negative values.
A variable which can store both positive and negative values.
A device that requires the application a single force to accomplish a task; i.e., a lever, pulley, or inclined plane.
The frictional force between two objects which are in relative motion and in contact with each other.
The loss of traction between two objects which are moving with respect to one another and in physical contact.
32.174 pounds-mass.
1. A coil of wire through which electricity passes, creating a magnetic field. 2. An electromagnet which is used to control a switch or valve.
Rapid, oscillating changes in pressure which are perceptible by the human ear.
An instrument that measures the relative intensity of different frequencies of electromagnetic radiation. Also called a spectrum analyzer.
A metal ring split into two halves, which make contact with the brushes of a motor to reverse the flow of electricity through the coils of the rotor.
The process of joining two pieces of sheet metal by passing a high electrical current through a small spot where the two pieces touch.
A wheel with metal teeth that mesh with a chain.
A wheel-like disk with teeth cut along the outside rim, all teeth being parallel to the axis of rotation.
An assembly of two gears of different sizes, fixed to a single axle. Also called a compound gear.
1. A torque value large enough to cause a motor to stop running. 2. The maximum torque output of a motor. Also called the torque rating.
The friction force between contacting surfaces that are not moving or sliding in any way.
The stationary part of an electric motor.
A type of electric motor which can rotate by steps to an exact angle.

A stroboscope, also known as a strobe, is an instrument used to make a cyclically moving object appear to be slow-moving or stationary. The principle is used for the study of rotating, reciprocating, oscillating or vibrating objects.
The rules controlling how program statements must be written in a computer program.
An instrument that measures the rotational speed of an object.
The linear velocity of a point on the rim of a rotating object.
A style of controlling a robot?s drive train using two joysticks. Each joystick controls the speed of one side of the robot?s drivetrain.
A style of controlling a robot's drive train using two joysticks. Each joystick controls the speed of one side of the robot?s drivetrain.
A hole which is threaded to receive a screw or bolt.
A miniature control panel which allows the operator to move a robot manually and run the robot's program one line at a time.
The practice of medicine by a physician who is separated from the patient by a great distance.
Controlled from a distance.

Programmatic step where the value of an expression is checked for equality, greater than, and/or less than some other value. Tests are used most often as decision points in a program, where based on the result, the program branches one way or another.
A cable used to carry signals between a transmitter and receiver in place of a radio.
A graph of the trace of an oscilloscope, showing the variation of voltage over time.
A short text displayed when the mouse pointer is held over an item.
The space between the top of a tooth of one gear and the bottom of the tooth space of a mating gear.
The front part of a gear tooth.
The thickness of a gear tooth.
1. A force applied at a distance from an axis of rotation. 2. The product of a linear force and the distance between the axis of rotation and the point of application of the force.
1. A torque value large enough to cause a motor to stop running. 2. The maximum torque output of a motor. Also called the stall torque.
A torsen differential is a planetary type differential in which the slower-moving wheel always receives more torque than the faster-moving wheel.
Kinetic friction between a drive member and the driving surface.
1. In engineering, a device which converts energy from one form to another. 2. In robotics, a device which converts electricity to another form of energy or vice versa.

A device used to transfer electric energy from one circuit to another, especially a pair of multiply wound, inductively coupled wire coils that effect such a transfer with a change in voltage, current, phase, or other electric characteristic.
Movement along a straight line.
A four-sided shape in which none of the opposing sides are parallel.
1. (verb) To adjust a variable resistor or capacitor. 2. (noun) Fine-controlled adjustment of a radio transmitter or receiver.
Not false. In programming, any non-zero value. By convention, always written in capital letters.
(adjective) Cut short.
A double-ended eyebolt with a left and right-handed thread in the central nut. Turning the nut increases or decreases the tension in the rod or wire to which the turnbuckle is attached.
Classification for programming variables.
Sound with a frequency above the range of human hearing.
Light with a frequency above the range of human vision.
Motion at a constant speed.
Motion under a constant acceleration.
A variable which only stores numbers greater than or equal to zero.
Capital letters like A, B, C, D, etc.
Code that is encapsulated into a named entity, and can be called from anywhere in a program. A user function often performs one specific task very well, and is named according to what it does.
A number or text string stored in a variable or used as a constant.
1. A symbol which represents a value which can be changed during the running of a computer program. 2. A symbol which stands for a location in computer memory.
A camera used by a robot to interpret its environment.
The measure of electrical potential.
A decline in the capacity of a rechargeable battery.
VHF (Very High Frequency) Omnidirectional Range; navigational equipment that helps pilots navigate to and from a given VOR station.
A mechanical device, such as a gripper arm, which copies the exact movements of a human limb.
The measure of the force exerted on an object due to gravity.
A battery whose electrolyte is a liquid.
The distance covered by a rolling wheel during one revolution, equivalent to the circumference of the wheel.
The area between the wheels of a vehicle.
Loops of wire used in an electric motor or electromagnet.
The amount of energy transferred by a force acting through a distance.
The space in which a robotic arm is able to reach and perform its intended task.
The depth of engagement of two mating gears.
A cylindrical gear with one or more teeth that spiral down the length of the gear.
A disk-shaped gear with teeth that mesh with a worm.
The loss of the most significant bit of a binary number, caused by exceeding the range of a variable.
In three-dimensional space, rotational motion around the vertical axis.
